bref_documents.title: Best Available Techniques Reference Document for the Intensive Rearing of Poultry or Pigs
bref_documents.scope_description: This BREF covers intensive rearing of poultry or pigs as defined in point 6.6 of Annex I to Directive 2010/75/EU. The document applies to installations for the intensive rearing of poultry or pigs with more than 40,000 places for poultry, 2,000 places for production pigs (over 30 kg), or 750 places for sows.

bat_conclusions.bat_title: Use of low emission housing systems
bat_conclusions.bat_description: In order to reduce ammonia emissions from pig housing, BAT is to use one or more of the following low emission housing systems with reduced emitting surfaces or techniques to reduce air velocity over the emitting surfaces, or to remove manure frequently from the building.
bat_conclusions.technique_description: Low emission housing systems include: sloped solid floors with urine drainage, partly slatted floors with solid areas for resting, floor cooling systems, air scrubbing systems, frequent manure removal systems.
bat_conclusions.implementation_guidance: The choice of housing system depends on animal welfare requirements, local climate conditions, and economic feasibility. New installations should prioritize these systems, while existing installations should implement during major renovations.

applicability.technical_feasibility: Applicable to new installations and major renovations. Retrofitting existing facilities may have limitations.
applicability.economic_feasibility: Cost-effective for new installations. Retrofit costs vary significantly.
exclusions: Facilities with less than 2000 animal places
special_conditions: Animal welfare requirements must be maintained
applicability.geographic_constraints: Applicable EU-wide with local climate considerations

emission_limit_values.measurement_conditions: Standard temperature and pressure, dry matter basis

monitoring_requirements.sampling_requirements: Representative sampling during normal operating conditions
monitoring_requirements.calibration_frequency: Annually or as per manufacturer specifications
monitoring_requirements.qa_qc_requirements: Quality assurance according to EN ISO/IEC 17025
monitoring_requirements.reporting_format: Annual environmental report format as per national regulations

relationships.description: Adequate ventilation systems enhance the effectiveness of low emission housing
Monitoring systems must be in place to verify housing system performance

bat_conclusions.investment_costs: Additional investment of 50-150 EUR per animal place compared to conventional housing
bat_conclusions.operating_costs: 5-15% increase in operating costs due to energy requirements and maintenance
bat_conclusions.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective considering environmental benefits and regulatory compliance
environmental_benefits: Reduced nitrogen deposition in sensitive ecosystems

bat_conclusions.bat_description: BAT is to ensure adequate ventilation in animal housing to maintain air quality while minimizing emissions through optimized air flow management and temperature control.
bat_conclusions.technique_description: Natural or mechanical ventilation systems with variable air flow rates, temperature control, and air distribution optimization. May include heat recovery systems.
bat_conclusions.implementation_guidance: Design ventilation systems based on animal requirements, building characteristics, and local climate. Ensure proper commissioning and regular maintenance.

applicability.technical_feasibility: Applicable to all installations with appropriate design
applicability.economic_feasibility: Cost varies with building size and complexity

monitoring_requirements.sampling_requirements: Representative sampling under normal operating conditions

relationships.description: Works synergistically with low emission housing systems

bat_conclusions.investment_costs: 10-30 EUR per animal place depending on system complexity
bat_conclusions.operating_costs: Increased energy costs offset by improved efficiency
bat_conclusions.cost_effectiveness: Generally cost-effective through improved feed conversion and health
environmental_benefits: Improved air quality in and around buildings

bat_conclusions.bat_description: BAT is to monitor emissions to air using standardized methods and frequencies appropriate to the scale and nature of emissions, with particular focus on ammonia, particulate matter, and odour.
bat_conclusions.technique_description: Continuous or periodic monitoring using standardized measurement methods. Includes both direct measurement and calculation methods based on emission factors.
bat_conclusions.implementation_guidance: Establish monitoring program appropriate to facility size and emission levels. Use accredited laboratories and certified measurement methods.

applicability.economic_feasibility: Costs scale with facility size and monitoring requirements
special_conditions: Frequency may be reduced for consistently compliant facilities

relationships.description: Monitoring is required to verify effectiveness of emission reduction techniques

bat_conclusions.investment_costs: 5000-25000 EUR initial setup costs depending on monitoring complexity
bat_conclusions.operating_costs: 2000-8000 EUR annually for ongoing monitoring and reporting
bat_conclusions.cost_effectiveness: Essential for regulatory compliance and optimization
